articles.headline: U.S.-Made Toys Benefit From China’s Troubles
articles.snippet: Manufacturers of American-made toys are emphasizing their products’ safety after Chinese product recalls.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers of American-made toys are emphasizing their products’ safety after Chinese product recalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whittle Shortline Railroad, a company in Louisiana, Mo., that makes wooden trains and trucks, posted a banner on its Web site several weeks ago: “100 percent kid-safe,” it read, “with lead-free paints.” Mike Whitworth, the company’s owner, said the recent recalls of Chinese-made toys found to contain lead in their paint has been good for his business. Very good.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighing Terrorist Label for Iran Guards
articles.snippet: The Bush administration is preparing to declare that Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps, a large branch of the military, is a foreign terrorist organization.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration is preparing to declare that Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps, a large branch of the military, is a foreign terrorist organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 — The Bush administration is preparing to declare that Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps is a foreign terrorist organization, senior administration officials said Tuesday.

articles.headline: 4 Truck Bombs Kill 190 in Kurdish Area of Iraq
articles.snippet: The blasts destroyed houses and sent hundreds of the wounded to at least six hospitals as far as 150 miles away, the Iraqi authorities said.
articles.abstract: The blasts destroyed houses and sent hundreds of the wounded to at least six hospitals as far as 150 miles away, the Iraqi authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Aug. 14  Four truck bombs killed at least 190 people on Tuesday in two villages in a Kurdish-speaking area near the Syrian border, destroying houses and sending hundreds of the wounded to at least six hospitals as far as 150 miles away, the Iraqi authorities said.

articles.headline: Two Giant Retail Chains Say Sales Are Slumping
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart and Home Depot reported earnings disappointments for the second quarter and predicted an even bumpier year ahead.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart and Home Depot reported earnings disappointments for the second quarter and predicted an even bumpier year ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart and Home Depot sneezed yesterday. Will the economy catch a cold?

articles.headline: Some Baby Bibs Said to Contain Levels of Lead
articles.snippet: Certain vinyl baby bibs sold at Toys “R” Us stores appear to be contaminated with lead, laboratory tests have shown.
articles.abstract: Certain vinyl baby bibs sold at Toys “R” Us stores appear to be contaminated with lead, laboratory tests have shown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 — Certain vinyl baby bibs sold at Toys “R” Us stores appear to be contaminated with lead, laboratory tests have shown, making the inexpensive bibs another example of a made-in-China product that may be a health hazard to children.

articles.headline: A Campaign Undeclared, Not Invisible
articles.snippet: On Fred D. Thompson’s Web site, supporters are solicited for donations and asked to promote him.
articles.abstract: On Fred D. Thompson’s Web site, supporters are solicited for donations and asked to promote him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee has not yet declared his presidential candidacy, he cannot advertise on television, on radio or in newspapers to promote his political ambitions.

articles.headline: Remembering a Classic Investing Theory
articles.snippet: David Leonhardt explores how an investing system of the past could aid analysis of today’s stock market.
articles.abstract: David Leonhardt explores how an investing system of the past could aid analysis of today’s stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 70 years ago, two Columbia professors named Benjamin Graham and David L. Dodd came up with a simple investing idea that remains more influential than perhaps any other. In the wake of the stock market crash in 1929, they urged investors to focus on hard facts — like a company’s past earnings and the value of its assets — rather than trying to guess what the future would bring. A company with strong profits and a relatively low stock price was probably undervalued, they said.

articles.headline: Subprime Problems Spread Into Commercial Loans
articles.snippet: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market bled into a type of short-term security held by money-market mutual funds.
articles.abstract: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market bled into a type of short-term security held by money-market mutual funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market spread again yesterday — this time to a type of short-term security held by money market mutual funds. These funds have become the investment of choice for many people seeking a safe haven.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Mattel Recalls 19 Million Toys Sent From China
articles.snippet: Amid a wave of increasing safety concerns about products made in China, Tuesday’s recall threatened to set the toy industry on its heels.
articles.abstract: Amid a wave of increasing safety concerns about products made in China, Tuesday’s recall threatened to set the toy industry on its heels.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mattel, the world’s largest toy company, yesterday announced the biggest recall in its history.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and David Barboza
